description: Like 'ee' in English 'see', but more tense. Lips spread.
Like 'i' in English 'sit'. A short, relaxed vowel.
Say 'ee' [iː] but with tightly rounded lips (like whistling).
Say the short 'i' [ɪ] sound but with rounded lips.
Like 'ay' in English 'say' but without the 'y' sound at the end. Tense.
Like 'e' in English 'bed'. An open, relaxed sound.
A longer version of the 'e' [ɛ] in 'bed'.
Say the tense 'ay' [eː] sound but with rounded lips.
Say the open 'eh' [ɛ] sound but with rounded lips.
Like 'oo' in English 'moon'. Lips tightly rounded.
Like 'oo' in English 'book'. A short, relaxed sound.
Like 'oa' in English 'boat', but one pure sound. Lips rounded.
Like 'o' in English 'hot' (British RP). An open, rounded sound.
A long 'ah' sound, like at the dentist. Very open.
A short 'ah' sound. Like the first part of English 'ouch!'.
The 'uh' sound (schwa), only in unstressed syllables. Like 'a' in English 'sofa'.
Like 'eye' or 'i' in English 'bike'.
Like 'ow' in English 'house'.
Like 'oy' in English 'boy'.
Like English 'p', but with less of a puff of air.
Like English 'b'. At the end of a word, it often sounds like [p].
Like English 't', but with less of a puff of air.
Like English 'd'. At the end of a word, it often sounds like [t].
Like English 'k', but with less of a puff of air.
Like English 'g' in 'go'. At the end of a word, it often sounds like [k].
Exactly like English 'f'.
The 'w' in German. Like English 'v' in 'van'.
A hissing 's' like in English 'see'.
A buzzing 'z' like in English 'zoo'. The sound of 's' at the start of a word.
The 'sh' sound in English 'shoe'. (sch, st, sp)
The 'soft ch' (Ich-laut). A hissing sound made by raising the front of the tongue. No English equivalent.
The 'hard ch' (Ach-laut). A rough, scraping sound from the back of the throat. Like Scottish 'loch'.
A breathy puff of air, like English 'h' in 'hat'.
Exactly like English 'm'.
Exactly like English 'n'.
The 'ng' sound in English 'king'.
The 'clear l' sound. The tongue tip is more forward than in English.
Can be a 'rolled' [r] at the front or a 'gargled' [ʁ] at the back (uvular). Both are common.
A 'p' and 'f' sound combined quickly. Start to say 'p', but release it into an 'f'.
A 't' and 's' sound combined quickly, like the 'zz' in 'pizza' or 'ts' in 'cats'. (z)
Like 'ch' in English 'church'. (tsch)
Like 'j' in English 'jam'. Only in loanwords.
Like 'y' in English 'yes'.
